item.title: Â∞ΩÁÆ°ÂâçÊîøÂ∫úÊé®Âä®ÂêàÊ≥ïÁöÑÂêåÊÄßÊÅãÂ©öÂßªÔºå‰ΩÜCuomoÂØπLGBTQÂõ¢‰ΩìÊîØÊåÅÊåëÊàòËÄÖÊÑüÂà∞‚ÄúÊ≤Æ‰∏ß‚Äù | Cuomo ‚Äòstonewalled‚Äô as LGBTQ groups endorse challengers ‚Äî despite ex-gov pushing through legal gay marriage
item.description:
Mayoral frontrunner Andrew Cuomo was stonewalled from endorsements by prominent Big Apple LGBTQ groups ‚Äî despite spearheading gay marriage in New York as governor.

Various political clubs instead decided to back his struggling challengers, naming Council Speaker Adrienne Adams and City Comptroller Brad Lander as their top picks in a ranked-choice Democratic Party primary for mayor in June.

‚ÄúNot the best news Andrew Cuomo ever got,‚Äù political operative Hank Sheinkopf quipped about the snub.

The endorsements come on the heels of Cuomo racking up a number of high-profile union endorsements as the former governor attempts a political comeback after resigning in 2019 amid sexual harassment allegations that he forcefully denied. Cuomo locked down one of the city‚Äôs final powerful unions in 1199SEIU late last week.

Gabriel Lewenstein, president of the Stonewall Democratic Club of NYC, skewered a ‚Äúselfish‚Äù Cuomo and endorsed Adams in the June primary.

‚ÄúAndrew Cuomo is all about himself. We want a mayor who cares about New Yorkers,‚Äù he railed as he praised her work as speaker.

‚ÄúAdrienne is exactly what New York City needs right now: a leader who is tenacious, smart, and possesses a deep understanding of the challenges in our city with bold plans to fix them.‚Äù

The nod follows Brooklyn‚Äôs LGBTQ political group, Lambda, which recently announced it had ranked Lander as its top choice in the crowded race, with state Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani and state Sen. Zellnor Myrie as next picks under ranked-choice.

Jim Owles Liberal LGBT Club also weighed in on the race, endorsing an unranked slate of candidates in Adams, Lander, state Sen. Jessica Ramos and Mamdani, the far-left, proud socialist who has consistently come up second in polls.

¬†Allen Roskoff, the head of Jim Owles, credited Cuomo for pushing through gay marriage, but called him ‚Äúunsuitable to be mayor.

‚ÄúThe gay community is smart,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to support Cuomo‚Äôs baggage. He‚Äôs not progressive by any stretch of the imagination.‚Äù

Adams railed against the Trump administration ‚Äúwaging war on the fundamental rights and dignity of New Yorkers‚Äù and vowed to fight back to protect LGBTQ rights if elected.

Lander said in a statement he was honored to get the endorsements and said he‚Äôll soon release his ‚ÄúLGBTQ+ platform to ensure New York City remains a beacon and safe haven.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one is surprised that Andrew Cuomo, the brainchild behind the disgusting ‚ÄòVote for the Cuomo, not the Homo‚Äô slogan from his father‚Äôs mayoral campaign, ‚Äù said Lander campaign spokesperson Dora Pekec ‚Äî referring to anti-gay guerilla campaign posters that appeared in the city when Cuomo‚Äôs father Mario Cuomo unsuccessfully ran against Ed Koch for mayor in 1977.

Andrew Cuomo has denied any involvement in the slogan or posters.

The ex-gov notably did not attend a mayoral forum with some of the groups on March 27, a campaign trend that he‚Äôs taken some heat for recently. He has only attended two forums in which he is questioned by a moderator on stage without any other candidates.

Cuomo‚Äôs camp downplayed the snubs, highlighting his track record with the community.

‚ÄúAndrew Cuomo looks forward to winning the votes of the LGBTQ community citywide, just as he has in the past, because New Yorkers know Andrew Cuomo doesn‚Äôt just pay lip service to the LGBTQ community issues, he delivers,‚Äù said campaign spokesperson Esther Jensen.

In 2011, the former governor signed legislation legalizing gay marriage in New York State.

Cuomo, as part of his tightly controlled campaign, continues to lock up labor and political endorsements.

Friday‚Äôs union announcement from 1199 brings him the backing of the largest health workers‚Äô union.
item.author: Carl Campanile, Craig McCarthy

item.title: ÂÖ±ÂíåÂÖöÁöÑËøàÂÖãÂ∞î¬∑‰∫®Âà©Ôºà Michael Henry ÔºâÂú®ÈáçÊñ∞ÊØîËµõ‰ª•Êé®ÁøªÈô∑ÂÖ•Âõ∞Â¢ÉÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÇ°‰ªΩÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëé±ËíÇË•ø‰∫ö¬∑Ë©πÂßÜÊñØÔºà Letitia James ÔºâÊó∂ÂãüÈõÜÊçêÊ¨æÔºö ‚ÄúÊèê‰ªÄËØ•Ëµ∞‰∫Ü‚Äù | GOP‚Äôs Michael Henry hauls in donations as he eyes rematch to topple embattled NY AG Letitia James: ‚ÄòTime for Tish to go‚Äô
item.description:
Republican Michael Henry said he‚Äôs raising the necessary funds for a rematch bid to topple embattled New York State Attorney General Letitia James next year.

Henry ‚Äî who ran a spirited bid against the incumbent Democrat in 2022 ‚Äî has received contributions from 6,000 donors, including from more than 1,200 New Yorkers who are eligible for matching funds.

The commercial litigator received a surprising 45% of the vote while losing to James three years ago ‚Äî but vowed this time will be different.

‚ÄúTogether, we will bring balance back to New York. It‚Äôs time to fight for every New Yorker ‚Äî and it‚Äôs time for Tish James to go,‚Äù Henry said.

Next year‚Äôs election will be the first time that statewide candidates can qualify for 6 to 1 public matching funds. Under the public finance program, a $25 donation generates $175, and a $100 donation counts as $700.

Henry claimed James has run a partisan operation.

‚ÄúThe attorney general‚Äôs office belongs to the people ‚Äî not political operatives,‚Äù he said.

James has made a name for herself by prosecuting President Trump‚Äôs business empire and commissioned an investigative report that concluded ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo harassed a slew of women, triggering his resignation.

But Trump ended up winning a second term and Cuomo, who denied the misconduct accusations, now is the Democratic front-runner in a comeback bid for New York City mayor.

James is now playing defense, deflecting bombshell accusations of mortgage fraud, and Henry said she has some explaining to do.

‚ÄúMortgage documentsüëâ she doesn‚Äôt deny the public records. and there is more to come!!!,‚Äù he said in an April 17 post on X.

The Trump-aligned America First Legal watchdog filed a complaint against James Monday with the New York State Unified Court System‚Äôs Committee on Professional Standards, which oversees disciplinary matters for lawyers licensed in the state, about the claims.

The group‚Äôs five-page missive rehashes allegations detailed in a letter seeking a federal criminal probe into James that was sent by Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) Director William Pulte to the Justice Department earlier this month.

Pulte said James appeared to have ‚Äúfalsified records‚Äù to obtain favorable home loans for a Virginia property and a Brooklyn apartment she owns.

But her lawyer, Abbe David Lowell, said the situation amounted to nothing more than a clerical error and accused Pulte of selectively including it to beef up his accusations.

Lowell said in a blistering letter to US Attorney General Pam Bondi last week that the accusations were nothing more than a meritless assault in Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúrevenge tour‚Äù against the prosecutor.

James‚Äô camp declined to comment on Henry‚Äôs challenge.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Âú®FDNYÁöÑÈ´òÁßëÊäÄÊú∫Âô®‰∫∫Ê∂àÈò≤ÈòüÂèäÂÖ∂Êú∫Ê¢∞Áãó‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫∫‰ª¨Êó†Ê≥ïÂà∞ËææÁöÑÂú∞Êñπ | Inside the FDNY‚Äôs high-tech robot firefighting team and its mechanical dogs that go where people can‚Äôt
item.description:
It‚Äôs not your grandfather‚Äôs FDNY.

New York‚Äôs Bravest are increasingly leading the world in the use of mechanized firefighters to snuff out blazes in the Big Apple ‚Äî and they‚Äôre sharing the wealth.

The department on Tuesday launched a three-day training class for area firefighting units to show off its fleet of high-tech smoke eaters that have become a vital part of the operation, showcasing everything from drones to forklifts to robotic canines that can go where no firefighter has gone before.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre very, very robust,‚Äù Capt. Michael Leo, who heads the FDNY Robotics Unit, told The Post. ‚ÄúThese were used in the parking garage collapse downtown. But where they excel is hazardous material situations, like lithium battery fires that we‚Äôre coming across more frequently.

‚ÄúThere are forklift robots which can lift a whole car up out of the way,‚Äù Leo said. ‚ÄúThey can fall down a flight of stairs, fall off subway platforms. Both have happened, by the way.‚Äù

This week‚Äôs training, which will culminate Sunday with a 73-story stair climb between real life firefighters and one of the robotic dogs, is training departments from Suffolk County, Syosset and Mineola, as well as members of the NYPD, city Emergency Management and MTA Bridges and Tunnels.

The FDNY unit is now 11-years old, and includes four officers and 12 ‚Äúpilots‚Äù ‚Äî trained operators of now-vital drones and robots who are among 50 throughout the department ranks.

Drones are particularly useful, using thermal imaging technology to detect hot-spots in high-rise fires and even structural weaknesses in buildings regardless of smoky conditions.

‚ÄúWe still have a firefighter going up whose responsible for, you know, seeing what‚Äôs going on on the roof,‚Äù Leo said. ‚ÄúBut now we‚Äôre also 200 feet above the fire, viewing the entire roof and we have a thermal imaging of what‚Äôs happening at the roof skin.‚Äù

A pair of $75,000 quadruped robotic dogs can also climb stairs in a burning building, fall several stories and get back up ‚Äî and are able to turn doorknobs or flip valves in situations too dangerous for firefighters.

While intense heat can still pose a problem ‚Äî melting chips and wires in the robots ‚Äî the department‚Äôs R&D crew is always looking for solutions, officials said.

In a display on Tuesday, one of the four-legged pups also had trouble keeping up with Leo in a push-up competition on the training grounds ‚Äî showing plenty of stamina but lacking the firefighter‚Äôs speed.

Nonetheless, the FDNY has drawn not only national interest in its mechanized members, and prompted departments as far off as Germany, Dubai and Japan to reach out for tips and advice, officials said.

‚ÄúThe FDNY is one of the leaders in our country for integrating robotics into their public safety programs,‚Äù Thomas Haus of the National Institute of Standards and Technology said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve really been an early adapter,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis new facility they have here is really quite amazing.‚Äù
item.author: Kevin Sheehan, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: ‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂÆâÁöÑÈïúÂ§¥ÊòæÁ§∫ÔºåÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥‰∏â‰∫∫ÁªÑÊÆ¥ÊâìÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Áà∏Áà∏Á∫¶Áø∞ÁöÑÂ∑•‰∫∫ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÂ∏¶ÁùÄ‰∏§‰∏™ÊØîËê®È•ºÈÄÉÁ¶ªÔºö ‚ÄúÂ∑•‰ΩúÂ§™Âç±Èô©‰∫Ü‚Äù | Disturbing footage shows teen trio pummeling NYC Papa John‚Äôs worker before fleeing with 2 pizzas: ‚ÄòToo dangerous to work‚Äô
item.description:
Disturbing footage shows a trio of teens pummeling a Bronx Papa John‚Äôs worker before fleeing with two stolen pizzas ‚Äî leaving the clerk afraid of returning to work because it is ‚Äútoo dangerous.‚Äù

The thugs ‚Äì two 18-year-olds and one 15-year-old ‚Äì barged into the fast food joint on East 204th Street near Decatur Avenue in Norwood around 11:30 p.m. Saturday and started an argument with worker Zakir Husain, 32, over their food order, according to cops and the victim.

Video shows one of the boys, wearing all red, leaning through the order window and talking before two of his pals walk through a door that appears to lead behind the counter.¬†

Seconds later, the trio drag Husain back through the door and begin thrashing him in the restaurant.

‚ÄúI say, ‚ÄòPlease, anybody call the police? Anybody call the police? Can anybody go lock [the door]?‚Äô‚Äù Husain told The Post in a phone interview.

‚ÄúHe pushed me outside, and he started punching,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúI am trying to lock the door and then he pushed me outside and punching ‚Äì he started punching.‚Äù

Three other customers can then be seen making a beeline for the door, the clip shows.¬†

Husain said the tensions first flared when pint-sized perps showed up at the store to pick up pizza they ordered through Uber Eats.

But a little while later, they came back with an empty box, though it wasn‚Äôt clear why.¬†

‚ÄúI just told him, ‚ÄòSir, you want more food?‚Äô I have to get the [permission] from my manager,‚Äù Husain explained.

He said he told the customer wearing all red that once he gets permission from his manager, all of his money would be refunded and he would get another pizza.¬†

However, the teen became increasingly irate and started swearing.¬†

Husain was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition. He said he was still in pain Tuesday and his ‚Äúhead is not working.‚Äù

Hussain said he was too out of sorts to remember how much food the suspects stole, but said his lawyer told him it was two boxes of pizza.¬†

He added that he did not know what he did to deserve the brutal beatdown.¬†

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happening to me? What is my wrong?‚Äù Husain said. ‚ÄúI say that ‚ÄòI just follow the rules, sir.‚Äô I just called [for] my manager‚Äôs permission, [then] I give you food. That‚Äôs simple rules.‚Äù

Adam Machado and Sinaly Siahoue, both 18, in addition to a 15-year-old boy whose name was not released because he is a minor, were arrested Monday and charged with second-degree robbery, cops said.¬†

But now Husain ‚Äì who said he was assaulted in the store just last year by a different suspect ‚Äì is wary about his safety at work.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if my life is safe or not safe,‚Äù Husain said.

‚ÄúSo many problems in here. Too much,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúYeah, it‚Äôs too dangerous. I think now it‚Äôs too dangerous to work.‚Äù
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: ÂÖ≥‰∫éË¢´ÊåáÊéßÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅ‰∏äÂº∫Â•∏Â∞∏‰ΩìÁöÑÂ∞èËñØÊù°ÁóÖ‰∫∫Âá∫Áé∞‰∫Ü‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂÆâÁöÑÊñ∞ÁªÜËäÇ‚ÄîÂåÖÊã¨‰ªñÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÈÅøÂÖçË¢´ÂèëÁé∞ | Disturbing new details emerge about small-fry sicko accused of raping corpse on NYC subway ‚Äî including how he avoided detection
item.description:
The small-fry sicko accused of repeatedly raping a corpse on a Lower Manhattan subway was crafty enough to stop the act when the train hit stations to avoid detection, it surfaced in court Tuesday.¬†

The twisted detail was made public as Felix Rojas, 44, was ordered held without bail at his arraignment in Manhattan Criminal Court, where prosecutors recounted his alleged heinous sexual assault and robbery of the dead man on an R train near the Whitehall Street station April 8.

Rojas, who appears to be about 5 feet tall, had bloodshot eyes as he told Judge Kacie Lally, ‚ÄúGood afternoon.‚Äù

Prosecutors described during the hearing how Rojas allegedly searched and raped the body of Jorge Gonzalez, 37, who had lost consciousness on a bench inside the train and died.¬†

The accused perv ‚Äútook advantage‚Äù of Gonzalez after realizing he remained motionless when Rojas went to search his pockets a second time, prosecutors said.¬†

Around 11:44 p.m. Rojas first sexually assaulted the victim, with his waist the same height as Gonzalez‚Äôs mouth as he was ‚Äúrepeatedly thrusting his hips back and forth,‚Äù it was revealed.

The act was caught on video surveillance, prosecutors said.

Rojas was careful enough to stop his despicable crimes between stations to avoid detection from incoming straphangers, prosecutors said.

He then allegedly moved Gonzalez‚Äôs body to the floor of the train car and removed his and the corpse‚Äôs pants to rape him, court papers reveal.¬†

The rapist would zip up his pants, pull Gonzalez‚Äôs trousers back up and wait on the train bench during stops before repeating his sick behavior when the subway starting moving again and no one was around, documents say.

He allegedly continued his perverted antics till 12:18 p.m. ‚Äî or for more than 30 minutes.

At 12:25 a.m., MTA police observed the motionless body on the floor of the train while Rojas was allegedly still in the subway car, prosecutors said.

Gonzalez was pronounced dead on arrival after FDNY medics responded to the scene.

He had boarded the subway around 8 p.m. that day before the suspect got on about three hours later, though it‚Äôs unclear where, sources previously told The Post.¬†

Rojas turned himself in to cops Sunday accompanied by his son, law-enforcement sources have said. A relative recognized his surveillance picture on the news, prosecutors said.¬†

After seeing a surveillance image of himself, Rojas told cops, ‚ÄúThat is me‚Äù but insisted he ‚Äúdid not do that,‚Äù authorities said.

When Rojas turned himself in to the NYPD, he submitted a ‚Äúpassport from another country,‚Äù prosecutors said.

His immigration status was not immediately known.

The city Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office said Tuesday¬†an autopsy was unable to determine how the Gonzalez died and that further study is required.

Sources have said police suspect Gonzalez succumbed to natural causes.

Gonzalez immigrated to the United States from Mexico about two decades ago in hopes of supporting his family back home, kin have said.

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt just a random person, he was a father, he was a family man, he cared about his family in Mexico,‚Äù said his 38-year-old wife, Teresa, who had been separated from Gonzalez for about six years.

‚ÄúHe did many things,‚Äù she recalled. ‚ÄúHe did construction, he worked in kitchens, he worked as a waiter, he was a busboy. You know, anything you really could do to try to get ahead.‚Äù

Rojas faces multiple charges for rape and grand larceny in the fourth degree, court papers show.

He will return to court May 2.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: CuomoË¶ÅÊ±ÇÊÄßÈ™öÊâ∞ÊåáÊéßËÄÖTrooper 1ÂÅøËøò860‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÔºåÁß∞Â•πÁöÑËØâËÆº‚ÄúÂÆåÂÖ®‰∏çÂèØÈù†‚Äù | Cuomo demands $8.6M payback from sexual harassment accuser Trooper 1, calls her lawsuit ‚Äòwholly unreliable‚Äô
item.description:
Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo is trying to toss the bombshell sexual harassment lawsuit brought by a state trooper on his detail ‚Äî claiming her claims were part of a conspiracy within the state police force to attack him while he was in office.

Cuomo finally filed a formal response Monday to the Brooklyn federal court suit brought three years ago by an anonymous woman known as Trooper 1 ‚Äî demanding that she pay back the $8.6 million in taxpayer-funded legal fees used so far for his defense.

‚ÄúTrooper 1‚Äôs allegations against him are false and were part and parcel of a plan to attack Governor Cuomo that Trooper 1 and other members of the NYSP planned, coordinated, and executed because they were disgruntled with Governor Cuomo for reasons entirely unrelated to any purported harassment or retaliation,‚Äù the filing states.

Cuomo ‚Äî who resigned in disgrace in 2021 and is now running for New York City mayor ‚Äî hasn‚Äôt paid a dime of his own money on legal fees in any of the sprawling litigation associated with his administration, which the state comptroller‚Äôs office reports now exceeds $61 million.

But his filing asks for him to be awarded ‚Äúinterest, attorney‚Äôs fees, costs, and disbursements, as permitted by law or statute.‚Äù

Cuomo also asks the judge to dismiss the suit ‚Äúwith prejudice,‚Äù meaning that the claims could not be refiled at a later date, while blasting the allegations as ‚Äúwholly unreliable and false hearsay.‚Äù

The court already tossed a retaliation claim from Trooper 1‚Äôs complaint, which was first filed in 2022, but her core accusations of sexual harassment remain.

The trooper said Cuomo asked for her to be transferred to his detail after the two met at a 2017 presser on the RFK bridge and she began working for him the following year before being moved to his travel team in 2019.

Her suit claims that Cuomo touched her stomach and back ‚Äî and kissed her on the cheek ‚Äî while she was on the job in 2019, among other undesirable behavior.¬†

Trooper 1‚Äôs attorney, Valdi Licul, fired back Tuesday, citing multiple investigations conducted by independent firms that found ‚Äúoverwhelming evidence‚Äù Cuomo engaged in sexual harassment, and ridiculed his request for payback.

‚ÄúThat hard-working taxpayers have had to pay millions of dollars ‚Äì and counting ‚Äì to fund Cuomo‚Äôs defense and his continued attacks on his victims is astounding,‚Äù Licul told The Post.¬†

‚ÄúHis request for fees is patently frivolous, not only because every independent investigation has found that he violated the law, but also because it appears that he hasn‚Äôt actually paid any fees.‚Äù¬†

Cuomo‚Äôs attorney, legal superstar Rita Glavin, blamed the three-year delay in filing the ex-gov‚Äôs pleadings ‚Äî as well as the hefty tab for legal expenses ‚Äî on the anonymous accuser,

Glavin claimed the plaintiff ‚Äúcopied and pasted‚Äù findings from the report conducted by state Attorney General Letitia James‚Äô office into sexual harassment allegations against Cuomo ‚Äúinto her complaint,‚Äù and refused to limit her legal action to her own accusations.

‚ÄúWe repeatedly asked Trooper 1 to drop those women from her suit to avoid this costly and unnecessary litigation, but she refused,‚Äù Glavin said. ‚ÄúAs a result, defense costs ballooned and nonparty witnesses were roped into the case. All of these decisions were outside of Governor Cuomo‚Äôs control. Trooper 1 could stop this at any moment by limiting her case to her own allegations, but she won‚Äôt.‚Äù

Attorneys for Cuomo are arguing for an expanded order of discovery that could include dozens and dozens of depositions from people named in the AG‚Äôs report, which found that the thrice-elected Democrat had sexually harassed multiple current and former state employees.

Cuomo, who said at the time that he ‚Äúnever touched anyone inappropriately or made inappropriate sexual advances,‚Äù resigned two weeks later.

A spokesperson for James said Tuesday that the AG‚Äôs office stands behind its investigation, adding that ‚Äúthe former Governor bears responsibility for his own actions, full stop.‚Äù

Taxpayers have shelled out over $61 million in legal fees stemming from Cuomo‚Äôs various scandals as of April 21.¬†

Those Cuomo controversies, which have also ensnared multiple state agencies, run the gamut from sexual misconduct accusations, impeachment proceedings, his COVID-19 pandemic response ‚Äî and his largely condemned, $5 million book deal for a memoir he penned as thousands of New Yorkers were succumbing to the virus daily.
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: ‚Äú‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÆËÇ§‰∏≠ÁöÑÊÅ∂È≠î‚ÄùÁßüÊà∑Âà©Áî®ÊØè‰∏™Ê≥ïÂæãÊºèÊ¥ûÂÖ•‰ΩèÊØèÊúà100ÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑÁöáÂêéÂå∫ÂÖ¨ÂØìÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê | ‚ÄòDemon in human skin‚Äô tenant uses every legal loophole to stay in $100-a-month Queens apartment: sources
item.description:
A tenant who hasn‚Äôt paid her $100-a-month rent in more than a decade is back in court, fighting to hold on to the two-bedroom Queens apartment she inherited through a controversial death-bed adoption, The Post has learned.

Maria DeTommaso, 74, has lived in the rent-controlled railroad flat on the bottom floor of a Long Island City row house since at least 2002, where neighbors say she causes many problems.

‚ÄúI think she‚Äôs a demon in human skin because of what she puts people through,‚Äù said Anjanie Narine, who has lived next door to DeTommaso for more than 20 years. ‚ÄúEvery interaction with her is negative. She terrorizes everyone, and acts as if she owns the building.‚Äù

DeTommaso scored her sweet rent deal when she moved in with an elderly former dock worker, Nicholas ‚ÄúNicky‚Äù DeTommaso, who had the original lease on the apartment. Days before he died in 2009, the then 58-year-old Maria convinced the 85-year-old retiree to adopt her.

Nine years later, the state‚Äôs Division of Housing and Community Renewal granted DeTommaso ‚Äúsuccessor rights‚Äù to the apartment, keeping its rent at $100 and allowing her to stay in perpetuity. Similar units in the building now rent just below $2,000.

During the time she has lived in the unit, neighbors say she has ‚Äúterrorized‚Äù them by renting out part of the apartment on Airbnb, ushering in a steady stream of dozens of tourists from around the world who rented rooms from her for $55 a night, according to complaints made to the Department of Buildings and online ads.

One longtime fellow tenant in the six-unit building said DeTommaso, who is also known as Pamela Becker and Prema Deodhar, has even changed the locks on the front doors and invited a steady stream of veterans from a nearby shelter who have caused havoc in the building.

For years, The Post has documented attempts by the building‚Äôs octogenarian owners, Sugrim and Kowsila Outar, to evict DeTommaso from the apartment. They are scheduled to return to Queens Housing Court on May 6.

‚ÄúHer case has already gone through five¬†of the¬†judges¬†here in Queens, and benefited from every change in the housing laws since COVID,‚Äù said Elan Layliev, the attorney for the Outars who is fighting to evict DeTommasso.

‚Äú[It‚Äôs been] a wild ride. Ms. DeTommaso has utilized every loophole in the court system to prolong and delay this trial.‚Äù

For her part, DeTommaso told The Post last week the claims against her are exaggerated and designed to kick her out of her home.

‚ÄúI won the succession,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is sick. I‚Äôm the legal tenant. I have every right to be here and I don‚Äôt know how people can lie so much. They are trying to evict me, but my lawyer says I don‚Äôt have to worry.‚Äù

DeTommaso‚Äôs lawyer, Zara Feingold, is a legal aid attorney who works with the New York Legal Assistance Group, according to court documents and her LinkedIn page, which means DeTommaso doesn‚Äôt have to pay her for representation.

Under New York law, she also doesn‚Äôt have to pay rent while the legal case with her landlords is ongoing, which is currently a decade. Still, she has prevoiusly said she puts rent money into an escrow account so it can be paid after the legal matter is settled.

DeTommaso, who lives with her two dogs ‚Äî a miniature grey hound and a dachshund ‚Äî told The Post she recently broke her hip in the apartment because the landlords have not done necessary repairs. She said her oven doesn‚Äôt work, and complained about roaches and mice in the living space.

However, according to Layliev, DeTommasso will not allow workers contracted by the Outars into her apartment and has previously hired homeless veterans to do the work and told them to present the bills to the owners.

DeTommasso was born Pamela Rose Becker on March 1, 1951. She grew up in Washington DC and attended a series of posh private schools. Her father served as US ambassador to Honduras during the Ford administration and her brother, Ralph Becker, is a former mayor of Salt Lake City.

A yoga enthusiast, she showed up at the Long Island City building to cat sit for a friend in the late 1990s. When the friend returned, she claimed she had nowhere to live and asked Nicky if she could spend a few days, said Narine.

She never left. Nicky, who was known in the neighborhood as ‚ÄúUncle Nicky,‚Äù had moved to the apartment in 1924 as an infant. He lived there with his mother, three brothers and two sisters, and stayed until his death on July 15, 2009.

A devoted ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù fan, he played stickball on the street when he was a child and chain-smoked cigarettes on the stoop, helping his neighbors secure parking spots when he was older, according to ‚ÄúNicky D from LIC: A Narrative Portrait‚Äù by writer and artist Warren Lehrer.

Five years after moving in, DeTommasso secured Nicky‚Äôs power of attorney in 2007. When his health was in decline, she drove him around the city to do errands and to see his doctor in a series of cars he bought for her, according to an interview with The Post in 2018.

‚ÄúHe loved me, and his whole family still calls me,‚Äù said DeTommaso last week.

But Narine, an office worker, said she recalled Nicky had allegedly tried to kick her out almost as soon as she moved in. ‚ÄúHe woke up early, and every morning I would hear him curse at her to get the f‚Äìk out,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm next door and the walls are pretty thin.‚Äù

The protracted battle with the Outars, immigrants from Guyana who also live in the building, has taken its toll on the elderly couple, claimed Narine, adding that Sugrim Outar, 85, has had several heart attacks over the years.

‚ÄúThey are both physically weak,‚Äù said Narine. ‚ÄúI have no doubt in my mind this battle with this professional squatter has taken years off their lives.‚Äù
item.author: Isabel Vincent

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂÖ±ÂíåÂÖöÂ∑ûÊÄªÈÉ®Âú®‰∏§Âë®ÂÜÖÁ¨¨‰∫åÊ¨°Ë¢´Á∫≥Á≤πÊ†áÂøóÊ±°ÊçüÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫È¢ÜÂØº‰∫∫Êï¶‰øÉÊ∞ë‰∏ªÂÖöÊ∑°ÂåñË®ÄËÆ∫ | NY GOP state headquarters defaced with Nazi symbols for second time in 2 weeks as leaders urge Dems to tone down rhetoric
item.description:
The New York state Republican Party‚Äôs Albany headquarters was defaced with Nazi imagery for the second time in two weeks ‚Äî as party leaders blamed Democrats for escalating political tensions.

The word ‚ÄúNazis‚Äù with an arrow pointed to it underneath was scribbled on the face of the building on State Street ‚Äî just two blocks from the state Capitol, the GOP said in a statement Tuesday.

The vandalism comes less than two weeks after printed images of the Nazi swastikas were taped to the doors and windows of the GOP building, which is also used for campaign events.

State GOP chairman Ed Cox.Cox blamed Senate Democratic Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and democratic socialist Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez for stoking anti-GOP hysteria.

‚ÄúChuck Schumer, with his constant demagoguery and past calls to political violence and AOC, with her present ‚ÄòFight the Oligarchy‚Äô tour, are fueling a climate of hostility that emboldens such hateful actors.

They must immediately call on their supporters to reject political violence and restore civility to our discourse,‚Äù Cox said.

He said both the Albany Police department and district attorney are investigating.

House GOP Rep. Elise Stefanik slammed the vandalism as a ‚Äúdirect threat‚Äù to Republican staff.

‚ÄúThis was not a random act of vandalism‚Äîit was an escalation of political hatred deliberately aimed at intimidating Republicans and silencing our voices,‚Äù Stefanik said.

Rockland Rep. Mike Lawler called on the culprits to be prosecuted ‚Äúto the fullest extent of the law.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe growing calls for political violence we‚Äôre seeing around the country are being fueled by Democrats like Chuck Schumer, JB Pritzker, Federica Wilson, and others, who have used reckless rhetoric and actions, calling for Republicans to ‚Äònot know a moment of peace,‚Äô saying Republicans are ‚Äòtraitors,‚Äô sending paid far-left activists to disrupt events, and creating a climate of hostility that emboldens and encourages these acts,‚Äù Lawler said.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÈÄâÊ∞ëÂÅáË£ÖÊàêÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∫∫Êäï‰∏ãÈÇÆÂØÑÈÄâÁ•®‚Äî‰ΩÜËÆ°ÂàíÂú®ÈÄâ‰∏æÊó•Á†¥Ë£ÇÔºöË≠¶ÂØü | Long Island voter cast mail-in ballot pretending to be someone else ‚Äî but plan fell apart on Election Day: cops
item.description:
A Long Island voter pretended to be someone else to cast an extra ballot in the 2024 election but his scheme was exposed when the resident he impersonated showed up on Election Day, cops said.

Lindenhurst resident Christopher Lindenberg, 54, was slapped with felony voter fraud charges for allegedly submitting a mail-in ballot under another person‚Äôs name before voting legally a second time, Suffolk County District Attorney Ray Tierney said.

Lindenberg had requested the early mail-in ballot through an online portal for another person without their knowledge last October.

The county Board of Elections initially counted the fraudulent vote but authorities first got suspicious when the real individual showed up to vote on Election Day and was turned away, the DA said.

It‚Äôs unclear if Lindenberg knew the person before the scheme. It‚Äôs also unclear whom the fraudulent ballot was cast for, but Lindenberg was a registered Republican, according to state records.

Lindenberg was arraigned Monday on a first-degree charge of offering a false instrument for filing and falsifying business records in the first degree.

He was released without bail because the charges are non-eligible and is due back in court on May 21.

‚ÄúConfidence in electoral systems is integral to a free society,‚Äù Tierney said in a statement.
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÂ∑ûÈïøHochul‰ª•Â∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑ2540‰∫øÁæéÂÖÉÈ¢ÑÁÆó‰∫§ÊòìÊèê‰æõÊñΩËàç‚Äî‰ªé400ÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑ‚ÄúÈÄöË¥ßËÜ®ËÉÄÈÄÄÊ¨æ‚ÄùÊîØÁ•®Âà∞ÂÖçË¥πÂ≠¶Ê†°ÂçàÈ§ê | NY Gov. Hochul boasts handouts ‚Äî from $400 ‚Äòinflation refund‚Äô checks to free school lunch ‚Äî in mammoth $254B budget deal
item.description:
It‚Äôs a free-for-all.

The handshake deal between Gov. Kathy Hochul and Albany lawmakers on a behemoth $254 billion state budget is loaded with handouts ‚Äî from ‚Äòinflation refund‚Äô checks to free school lunch.

Hochul, when announcing the ‚Äúgeneral agreement‚Äù¬†late Monday, boasted that her freebies will save New York families thousands of dollars.

‚ÄúWhen you add all this up ‚Äî your family‚Äôs inflation refund, school breakfast and lunch, the child tax credit for your little ones, plus the middle class tax cut ‚Äî that‚Äôs $5,000 back in the pockets of New York families,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how you make a tangible difference in people‚Äôs lives.‚Äù

The $5,000 worth of freebies are part of what Hochul has touted as her ‚Äúaffordability‚Äù agenda for everyday New Yorkers as she and fellow Democrats in the Legislature haggled over the record-breaking, bank-busting budget ‚Äî which nonetheless includes a tax increase on businesses to fund the MTA‚Äôs ambitious $68 billion capital plan.

The marquee handout in the preliminary deal is perhaps the up-to-$400 checks being sent out to New Yorkers later this year.

Hochul secured $2 billion for what are misleadingly dubbed ‚Äúinflation refund checks,‚Äù despite disdain from fiscal hawks who lambasted them as an ineffective use of funds.

Individuals and families will received if they fall under the following fiscal thresholds:

  • Families making under $150,000: $400
  • Families making between $150,000 and $300,000: $300
  • Individuals making under $75,000: $200
  • Individual making between $75,000 and $150,000: $150¬†

The one-time checks will be greeted with a sigh of relief from New Yorkers who‚Äôve been hit by ever-increasing prices, Hochul predicted.

‚ÄúIf anybody questions whether or not an inflation rebate is a good idea, go with me to a grocery store and walk and push a shopping cart as a mom is putting everything from eggs to diapers and bread and tuna fish in the cart,‚Äù she said.

The checks will also come alongside a measly 0.1% decrease in income taxes for individuals making less than $215,400 and families making less than $323,200 for 2026.

They can expect another 0.1% reduction in 2027.

Families with children, however, can expect an even bigger bit of tax relief.

The child tax credit will be expanded for two years under the plan, resulting in up to $1,000 tax credits for each kid aged 0 to 3 for most families in 2025 and $500 for each youngster aged 4 to 16 the following year.

The expanded credit is expected to cost around $800 million over the two fiscal years.

‚ÄúThe child tax credit I think is going to be an extraordinary change to help families, particularly those that are struggling, lift them out of poverty,‚Äù Hochul said.

Schools will also now have to serve breakfast and lunch to students free of cost, under changes adopted in the spending plan.

Hochul‚Äôs budget office estimates this will cost the state an additional $340 million a year.
item.author: Vaughn Golden, Matt Troutman

item.title: Ozempic Ôºå WegovyÂÆûÁé∞‰∫ÜÊàëÁöÑÊÑøÊôØÔºå 11Â≤ÅÁöÑÂ•∂Â•∂ÂíåÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÁî∑Â≠êËØ¥‚ÄîÈöèÁùÄË∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ§öÁöÑÁî®Êà∑Êä•Âëä‚ÄúÊØÅÁÅ≠ÊÄß‚ÄùÁöÑÂâØ‰ΩúÁî® | Ozempic, Wegovy took my vision, say grandma of 11 and NJ man ‚Äî as more users report ‚Äòdevastating‚Äô side effect
item.description:
A grandma of 11 and a New Jersey man have joined the growing chorus of users of the wildly popular weight-loss drugs Ozempic and Wegovy who say they didn‚Äôt just lose fat ‚Äî they also lost their eyesight.

New local lawsuits filed by the pair allege the manufacturer hid the ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù risk, which left them with a permanent, life-changing loss of vision in both eyes.

‚ÄúIt pains me to think I won‚Äôt be able to fully see my grandchildren‚Äôs faces and fully experience the biggest moments of my loved ones‚Äô lives,‚Äô‚Äô said plaintiff Cilette Mitchell, a 64-year-old grandmother and former vice president at a large commercial bank in California, to The Post.

‚ÄúHad I known that Ozempic would take my vision, I would have never taken it.‚Äù

Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk is accused in the suits of being ‚Äúdeceptive and misleading about the true risks‚Äù of the hit GLP-1 obesity drugs, with the legal documents citing multiple studies suggesting that the potential for a blindness-causing ‚Äúeye stroke‚Äù doubles with the use of them.

The lawsuits insist the manufacturer has a responsibility to warn doctors and users ‚Äúof the complications and devastating effects‚Äù of the drugs ‚Äî which are so popular that they raked in more than $25 billion in global sales last year.

But Novo Nordisk has ‚Äúfailed‚Äù to communicate the ‚Äúclinically relevant information‚Äù that a risk of irreversible blindness exists, the suits allege.

The two sight-addled patients filed lawsuits against the drugmaker in New Jersey state court last week. The company‚Äôs US headquarters are in Plainsboro, NJ.

Both plaintiffs said in their suits that they began taking the weight-loss drugs in 2023 and, in addition to losing some weight, noticed blurriness in their vision months after their first injection.

Mitchell, a mother of four, said she started noticing ‚Äúdark, cloudy shadows‚Äù in her right eye just three months into her regime, first with Wegovy, and then Ozempic.

An ophthalmologist urged her to rush to the emergency room for an MRI, where she was diagnosed with Non-Arteritic Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy, or NAION, in her right eye, she said.

Things got worse weeks later on Easter Sunday, she said.

‚ÄúWhile playing with my grandchildren, the dark clouds started to creep in on my other eye,‚Äù Mitchell said.

‚ÄúThe next day, the doctor confirmed that I developed NAION in that eye as well, with the result being permanent vision loss.‚Äù

Mitchell, who was near retirement, started taking classes at the San Diego Center for the Blind to see if she would be able to return to her job at the bank ‚Äî where she could no longer see a computer screen.

But vision and balance issues from NAION have halted working altogether, her suit states.

‚ÄúNow I need help doing daily activities and navigating life,‚Äù Mitchell said.

The New Jersey patient, who declined to comment to The Post, claims in his suit that he was diagnosed with bilateral NAION about a month after he first had issues with his vision.

The man says in his suit that he ‚Äúcan no longer drive, can no longer read, and is completely dependent on his wife for day-to-day assistance.‚Äô‚Äô

His neuro-ophthalmologist told him that his vision would never recover, the court document states.

The drugmaker said in a statement to The Post that the users‚Äô vision condition, NAION, is ‚Äúrare‚Äù and ‚Äúnot an adverse drug reaction‚Äù from its products.

The manufacturer cited its own internal studies and research from the University of Southern Denmark in making the claim.

‚ÄúNovo Nordisk is of the opinion that the benefit-risk profile of [the alleged culprit ingredient] semaglutide remains unchanged,‚Äù a company rep told The Post.

But Craig Silverman, the lawyer for the two patients, said the plaintiffs ‚Äústrongly reject Novo Nordisk‚Äôs dismissive attempt to minimize the serious risks associated with its blockbuster weight loss drugs.‚Äù

The two lawsuits cite studies which claim NAION links to the drugs, including 2024 research published in the the Journal of the American Medical Association.

The study found that users of the drugs were far more likely to develop NAION but also notes further research of the causation is needed.

The suits note that the drugmaker‚Äôs ‚Äúwarning labels are still devoid of any mention of NAION.‚Äù

Other former users of the weight-loss drugs have also recently filed suits against the drugmaker claiming the GLP-1 medications possibly caused their NAION, as well.
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: Â∑≤ÊïÖÊòéÊòüËè≤Âà©ÊôÆ¬∑Ë•øÊë©¬∑ÈúçÂ§´ÊõºÔºà Philip Seymour Hoffman ÔºâÁöÑÂ•≥ÊúãÂèãÂä†ÂÖ•Zohran MamdaniÁ´ûÈÄâÂπøÂëä‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖ∂‰ªñÂØåÊúâÁöÑÂ∑¶ÊíáÂ≠ê | Girlfriend of late star Philip Seymour Hoffman joins other wealthy lefties in Zohran Mamdani campaign ad
item.description:
Wealthy lefty supporters of Democratic Socialist Zohran Mamdani ‚Äî including the longtime girlfriend of late actor Philip Seymour Hoffman ‚Äî appear in the mayoral candidate‚Äôs first TV ad.

Mimi O‚ÄôDonnell, the mother of Hoffman‚Äôs three children, is seen excitedly jumping up and down with a Mamdani sign toward the end of the 30-second spot.

‚ÄúI love a progressive candidate. He‚Äôs got the energy. I love free child care, free buses. I like all the stuff he‚Äôs said,‚Äù said O‚ÄôDonnell, who resides in a multimillion-dollar pad in the tony West Village, to The Post.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like [Eric] Adams, I don‚Äôt like [Andrew] Cuomo,‚Äù she said, referring to the mayor and former governor also running for City Hall.

O‚ÄôDonnell has worked as a TV and podcast costume designer, director and executive producer for such series as ‚ÄúA Gifted Man,‚Äù ‚ÄúSandra‚Äù and ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live.‚Äù She also worked as the head of scripted fiction at Spotify.

O‚ÄôDonnell said wealthy people such as herself should support a Democratic Socialist agenda that helps the needy.

‚ÄúWe have it to give. There are enough people in the city that have it to give,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much wealth in the city. It‚Äôs insane that there is so much wealth out there, and there‚Äôs such a disparity,‚Äù O‚ÄôDonnell added.

‚ÄúWe need to think differently. [Mamdandi] is a breath of fresh air.‚Äù

O‚ÄôDonnell ‚Äî whose Oscar-winning longtime love Hoffman died of a heroin overdose in Manhattan in 2014 ‚Äî said she offered to volunteer on Mamdani‚Äôs campaign and was invited to appear in the Queens state assemblyman‚Äôs campaign ad.

Political consultant Hank Sheinkopf, who represents law enforcement unions, said working-class folks can‚Äôt afford Mamdani.

‚ÄúThe rich can afford everything. We can‚Äôt,‚Äù Sheinkopf said when hearing about Mamdani‚Äôs ad.

‚ÄúMamdani wants to get rid of cops. The wealthy can afford private security. The rest of us can‚Äôt. We‚Äôre going to end up getting mugged.‚Äù

Another artist appearing in the ad is Vivienne Leheny, an actress and audiobook narrator who has recorded 200 audiobooks.

Leheny said she enjoyed being part of the filming on what was a ‚Äúchilly‚Äù day.

‚ÄúMamdani stands a league above the other candidates. He‚Äôs setting the agenda, and the others are playing catch-up,‚Äù said Leheny, who described herself as well-off middle-class.

Mamdani‚Äôs comrades with the Democratic Socialists of America also make appearances in the spot.

Diana Moreno, co-chair of the DSA Queens branch, who has been arrested multiple
times at anti-Israel protests, is shown holding an infant about halfway into the ad.

Mamdani‚Äôs campaign thanked his supporters for the cameos.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so grateful for the New Yorkers who volunteered their time to appear in our first television ad and help introduce Zohran‚Äôs message of a more affordable city to a wider audience,‚Äù a Mamdani campaign spokesman said.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑û‰∏ãÁè≠Â•≥Ë≠¶ÂØüÂõ†Ê∂âÂ´åÈóØÂÖ•ÂÆ∂‰∏≠ÊÆ¥Êâì‰∏§‰∫∫ËÄåË¢´Êçï | Off-duty female NJ cop arrested for allegedly assaulting two people after breaking into their home
item.description:
An off-duty female cop in New Jersey was arrested for allegedly smashing her way into a home and then assaulting two people inside in a violent home invasion, authorities said.

Toms River Police Officer Rebecca A. Sayegh ‚Äî who previously sued her department for alleged sexual harassment ‚Äî is accused of breaking into the house in Berkeley Township just before 11:30 p.m. Friday, the Ocean County Prosecutor‚Äôs Office said.

The 32-year-old cop allegedly ‚Äúsmashed the front glass door‚Äù of the property before assaulting and threatening the two people who lived there.

Moments before the alleged home invasion, the off-duty cop also trashed the hood of one of the victims‚Äô cars parked in the driveway of the Evernhan Avenue¬†home, prosecutors alleged.

It wasn‚Äôt immediately clear if ‚Äî or how ‚Äî Sayegh knew the others involved.

However, Prosecutor Bradley Billhimer¬†said officers had responded to a ‚Äúdomestic disturbance.‚Äù

Sayegh was cuffed at the scene after initially resisting arrest, authorities said.

She was slapped with a slew of charges, including home invasion burglary, assault, criminal mischief, terroristic threats, and resisting arrest.

The cop is being held at the Ocean County Jail pending a detention hearing.

‚ÄúAs per our chief of police, we do not have a comment on the matter and refer all inquiries to the Ocean County Prosecutor‚Äôs Office,‚Äù Toms River police Lt. Ron Sermarini told the Asbury Park Press when asked about the officer‚Äôs arrest.

The ordeal comes roughly six months after Sayegh hit her employer with a lawsuit alleging that a ‚Äúboys club‚Äù in the department ranks resulted in her being sexually harassed and passed over for promotions.

News 12 reported the officer was honored for courage after running into a burning home to save a woman and her pets.
item.author: Emily Crane

item.title: Â§±Ë∏™ÁöÑÈïøÂ≤õÊ∞ë‰∏ªÂÖö‰∫∫Petros KrommidasÁöÑÊ±ΩËΩ¶ÂíåË°£ÊúçÂú®Êµ∑Êª©ÈôÑËøëË¢´ÂèëÁé∞ | Missing Long Island Democrat Petros Krommidas‚Äô car and clothes found near beach
item.description:
The clothes and phone of missing Long Island Democrat Petros Krommidas have been found on a beach close to his car, his family said ‚Äî as they revealed he likely swam in the sea while training for an upcoming triathlon.

Krommidas, who is running for a seat on the Nassau County Legislature, hasn‚Äôt been seen since he set off for a training swim last Wednesday night at Long Beach, according to cops and his family.

The 29-year-old‚Äôs locked car was later found parked by the Allegria Hotel ‚Äî just off the beach he regularly goes to, his family said in a social media post.

‚ÄúHe locked his car, took a towel, and around 10:30 p.m. walked onto the beach to exercise, just as he had done many times before,‚Äù they wrote.

‚ÄúHe has always been in great shape and was training for a triathlon. He was not a stranger to cold water training,‚Äù the post stated.

His family reported him missing the following day, noting it was ‚Äúcompletely out of character for him not to respond.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe police found his towel, clothes, and phone left on the beach. Since then, search efforts have been ongoing, but we need the public‚Äôs help,‚Äù the family said in the post.

‚ÄúSpecifically, we need people to walk the beaches ‚Äî focused between from Lido Beach to Riis Park ‚Äî particularly during times of high tide.‚Äù

Just two days prior to his vanishing, Krommidas¬†‚Äî a former student-athlete at Columbia University ‚Äî had addressed the Nassau County Young Democrats‚Äô monthly meeting ahead of his election primary on June 24.

The Long Island native had worked in finance, including at Morgan Stanley and Sageview Capital, before throwing his hat in the political ring in 2024 with a job as a Democratic Party field organizer.

‚ÄúWe are heartbroken over the disappearance of Petros Krommidas,‚Äù Nassau County Democratic Committee Chairman Jay Jacobs said in a statement.

‚ÄúPetros is a bright, driven young man who has been a strong voice for Democratic values. He is well respected by the community and represents the very best of our next generation of leaders. We are keeping Petros and his family in our prayers and remain hopeful for his safe return.‚Äù

Police said Krommidas¬†was last seen wearing a camouflage shirt and gray sweats. He is described as a male white, 6‚Äô2‚Äù tall, 230 pounds, with brown hair and brown eyes.
item.author: Emily Crane

item.title: Viral TikToksÂò≤Á¨ëÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏é‚ÄúÂèëÂ±ï‰∏≠ÁöÑ‚Äù‰∏≠ÂõΩÁõ∏ÊØîÔºö ‚ÄúÁæéÂõΩÁöÑÈí±ÂéªÂì™ÂÑø‰∫ÜÔºü‚Äù | Viral TikToks mock NYC subway system with comparison to ‚Äòdeveloping‚Äô China: ‚ÄòWhere does America‚Äôs money go?‚Äô
item.description:
Footage mocking New York City‚Äôs subway system has gone viral on TikTok ‚Äî with a slew of social media clips ridiculing US infrastructure in comparison to China.

One video, shared by user Schbachlq on the Chinese-owned social platform, blasted out footage of water cascading from the ceiling of Brooklyn‚Äôs Jefferson Street station, as well as burst pipes at Manhattan‚Äôs 34th Street stop.

Scores of rats, meanwhile, could be seen hauling food and trash as they scurried around underground.

In stark contrast, the clip ‚Äî which noted the US was a ‚Äúdeveloped country‚Äù ‚Äî quickly cut to footage of pristine transit hubs across a ‚Äúdeveloping‚Äù China.

The footage ‚Äî viewed more than 2.5 million times already ‚Äî bragged of air trains zooming through Wuhan and a pearly white subway station in Shenzen.

‚ÄúWhere does America‚Äôs money go?‚Äù the video was captioned, comparing the two countries‚Äô GDPs.

Other similar videos, which have been viewed tens of thousands of times, compared homeless people camping out across the US to footage of Chinese locals strolling down immaculate streets.

‚ÄúDo you know how much China used to admire the US,‚Äù one of the clips stated.

‚ÄúThey saw America as a mentor and tried to learn everything from it.‚Äù

The mocking clips come as a trade war over President Trump‚Äôs harsh tariffs continues to escalate after the US raised levies on Chinese imports to 145%.

Beijing quickly retaliated by slapping retaliatory duties of 125% on US goods.
item.author: Emily Crane

item.title: ÂâçÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç‰ª£ÁêÜÊïôÂ∏àÂàÜÂèë‰∫Ü1,500Â§öÂº†ÂÑøÁ´•Ëâ≤ÊÉÖÂõæÁâá‚ÄîÂåÖÊã¨Â©¥ÂπºÂÑøÔºöËÅîÈÇ¶Ë∞ÉÊü•Â±Ä | Ex-NYC acting teacher distributed more than 1,500 child porn images ‚Äî including of infants and toddlers: feds
item.description:
A former Big Apple acting teacher allegedly passed around a disturbing trove of child porn with over a thousand files ‚Äì including images depicting the sexual abuse of toddlers and infants ‚Äì over a short few months, according to federal prosecutors.

Actor and dancer Samuel Gonzalez, 31, was arrested Monday, more than two years after he first made contact with an undercover federal agent and began sharing the sickening content, a criminal complaint alleged.

The Brooklyn resident allegedly used an online messaging app to send the covert investigator links that contained more than 1,500 files of child porn between January and April of 2023, the US Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Southern District of New York said.¬†

Later that year, the feds seized a slew of his electronic devices, including his cell phone and laptop, which allegedly held 18 videos and 69 photos of child pornography.

Some files showed infants as young as just a few months old, the feds said. ¬†

‚ÄúAs alleged, Samuel Gonzalez distributed a large volume of child pornography, including images of sexual abuse of children as young as a few months old,‚Äù Manhattan US Attorney Jay Clayton said in a statement.

‚ÄúThe lasting scars from the horrific abuse of children are deeply troubling to all New Yorkers. Together with our partners, we will relentlessly pursue those who victimize children and prosecute them to the fullest extent of the law.‚Äù

Gonzalez previously taught at the Atlantic Acting School in Manhattan‚Äôs Chelsea neighborhood, but hasn‚Äôt since May 2021 and is no longer connected to the institution, a school spokesperson said in an email.¬†

He was charged with a count each of distribution of child pornography and possession of child pornography. If convicted on the charges, he could face decades in prison.

‚ÄúSamuel Gonzalez allegedly distributed thousands of pornographic images of infants and minors to an undercover federal agent over a brief period,‚Äù FBI Assistant Director in Charge Christopher Raia said in a statement.

‚ÄúGonzalez‚Äôs alleged actions grossly disregarded the victims‚Äô welfare and repeatedly violated their privacy by sharing this twisted material.‚Äù

Gonzalez hung up when a Post reporter inquired about the charges against him Monday night. A phone call and email to his public defender were also not returned. ¬†

He was released from custody after his arraignment Monday, a US Attorney‚Äôs spokesperson said.
item.author: David Propper

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÈúç‰∏òÂ∞îÁ´ãÊ≥ïËÄÖÂ∞±‰Ω©Êà¥Èù¢ÂÖ∑ÁöÑÁΩ™ÁäØËææÊàêÂçèËÆÆ | Hochul, NY lawmakers reach agreement on mask-wearing criminals
item.description:
The New York state budget deal includes a new law that would tack on an extra charge for perps who wear masks while committing another crime, Gov. Kathy Hochul said Monday.

The governor and state lawmakers finally struck a deal ‚Äî though it‚Äôs a far cry from an outright mask ban that some advocates were pushing for in response to out-of-control anti-Israel protests that have been filled with menacing masked demonstrators.

The agreed-to penalty could only be leveled if a suspect is charged with a class A misdemeanor or anything more serious, according to Hochul, who initially wanted stronger legislation.

Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie also confirmed the mask law deal attached to the $254 billion state spending plan while talking to reporters in Albany earlier Monday.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really trying to concentrate on people who wear a mask in regards to hiding their identity while they commit another crime,‚Äù Heastie said, according to Gothamist. ¬†

State Sen. James Skoufis, who pushed for harder mask restrictions, told the outlet the new charge would be a class B misdemeanor and would also apply to suspects covering their faces while fleeing a crime scene.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs an important acknowledgement, and it‚Äôs a response to a very legitimate issue that is very strongly felt by a lot of New Yorkers, including the Jewish community,‚Äù the Democrat said.

‚ÄúWe are at least doing something. It‚Äôs narrower than I would‚Äôve liked.‚Äù

Wearing masks in public was outlawed in the state before the ban was lifted at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Hochul originally wanted to create an increased penalty if someone hid their face while threatening a group of people, but lefty lawmakers balked at that proposal ‚Äî and civil liberty activists also voiced concern, leading to the narrower law agreed to this week.

The contentious issue was first raised after a wave of off-the-rails anti-Israel protests engulfed the Big Apple with mask-wearing goons directing antisemitic hate toward city Jews last year.

‚ÄúThis is a step forward in an addressing a crisis that has spiraled out of control in New York, as masked up individuals have used face and head coverings as tools of terror to target and menace,‚Äù Will Miller, a spokesperson for #UnMaskHateNY, wrote in a statement noting that ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt done.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are committed for the long haul to ensure that legislation meets the crisis.‚Äù
item.author: Vaughn Golden, David Propper

item.title: Êö¥ÂæíÂêå‰ºôÂú®Ê∂âÂèäË≠¶ÂØü„ÄÅÊïôÂ∏àÁöÑLIÂçñÊ∑´Âõ¢‰ºô‰∏≠Ë¢´Êçï‚ÄîÁé∞Âú®Ê£ÄÂØüÂÆòÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰ªñ‰ª∑ÂÄº120‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑÁÅ´Â≤õÊµ∑Êª©ÊàøÂ±ã | Mob associate busted in LI prostitution ring involving cop, teacher ‚Äî now prosecutors want his $1.2M Fire Island beach house
item.description:
Long Island prosecutors are looking to seize a $1.2 million home on Fire Island from the accused boss of a long-running prostitution ring that allegedly operated two brothels across Suffolk County with help from a cop and a gym teacher, court records show.

The ritzy beachfront home is part of a $1.96 million civil forfeiture case filed against Frank Saggio, a 60-year-old convicted felon and admitted associate of the mafia, who claimed to have worked for all five major New York families.¬†

The Ocean Beach property was paid for with money raked in through the illegal scheme, and purchased by a corporation controlled by Saggio using proceeds from a brothel in Holbrook, according to prosecutors.¬†

Saggio, of West Islip, and his mistress, 32-year-old Dana Ciardullo, of East Meadow, were busted in October alongside Islip gym teacher Steven Arey, 54, and veteran six-time Suffolk ‚ÄúCop of the Month‚Äù George Trimigliozzi, 56, in a sweeping 58-count indictment accusing them of enterprise corruption and promoting prostitution, court records show.

‚ÄúIt is a sad day in law enforcement when a public servant is arrested,‚Äù Suffolk DA Ray Tierney said at the time of the arrests.

Saggio allegedly ran the brothels from October 2019 through June 2024.

Trimigliozzi and Arey acted as managers at the American Girls Spa location in Holbrook along Sunrise Highway, while Ciardullo ran the West Babylon spot inside an adult store known as Tunnel of Love, prosecutors said.

The crew allegedly forced the prostitutes to sign ‚Äúleases‚Äù for the rooms they worked out of ‚Äî charging them $6,000 a month to work in Holbrook and $12,000 in West Babylon, but they weren‚Äôt paid for their services and only earned tips, according to prosecutors.

The alleged ringleader used a shell company named after the Holbrook brothel‚Äôs address, 6801 Sunrise Highway, to collect illegal payments disguised as ‚Äúrent,‚Äù court papers show.¬†

Meanwhile, his wife, Lisa Piazza Saggio, was listed as the company‚Äôs sole officer, but prosecutors claim it was just a front for Saggio himself.

In July 2022, Saggio unloaded the Holbrook property for $1.2 million ‚Äî and within two months, dropped $1.25 million on a beach house at 24 Bungalow Walk, which prosecutors allege was part of a scheme to launder dirty cash from the brothel.

While prosecutors try to claw the house back, Saggio, Ciardullo, Trimigliozzi and Arey all still face criminal charges tied to the alleged racket.

All four have pleaded not guilty, according to court docs.¬†
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Ë¢´ÊåáÊéßÊä¢Ëµ∞Kristi NoemÁöÑGucciÈí±ÂåÖÁöÑÈùûÊ≥ïÁßªÊ∞ëÂú®‰∏ä‰∏™ÊúàÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂèëÁîüÁ±ª‰ººÁäØÁΩ™ÂêéË¢´ÈáäÊîæ | Illegal migrant accused of snatching Kristi Noem‚Äôs Gucci purse was free after similar crime in NYC last month
item.description:
This guy‚Äôs a Noem criminal.

The illegal migrant who was busted for snatching Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem‚Äôs¬†Gucci purse was picked up by cops in New York for a similar crime just a few weeks earlier ‚Äî but they let him go with a desk appearance ticket and a court date.

The NYPD‚Äôs warrant squad was hunting for Chilean national Mario Bustamante-Leiva, 49 ‚Äî because he never showed up to court ‚Äî when he allegedly ripped off Noem during Easter dinner with her family at a Washington, DC, burger bar, law enforcement sources told The Post.

After swiping Noem‚Äôs purse ‚Äî which contained $3,000 cash, her passport, wallet and government ID ‚Äî he hopped a bus and sidled up to the bar at Angolo Ristorante Italiano in DC, where he boozed it up until midnight and rang up $205.87 on the DHS honcho‚Äôs American Express, according to documents released by prosecutors Monday.

The feds also released surveillance images of Bustamante-Leiva wearing a white face mask and a baseball cap before and after he allegedly stole Noem‚Äôs $4,000 luxury bag from under her feet at The Capital Burger. Another picture allegedly showed the accused serial thief at Angolo ‚Äî Noem‚Äôs Gucci bag clearly in view ‚Äî while chatting on the cell phone.

The high-profile theft was the fourth he pulled off in eight days, authorities said. He copped to stealing Noem‚Äôs bag, but said he didn‚Äôt know who she was when he snatched the pricey bag from the floor while she dined, according to court docs.

Bustamante-Leiva‚Äôs rap sheet also includes a 2021 shoplifting arrest in Utah and a headline-grabbing bust across the pond in London in 2015, where he was arrested for a months-long theft spree and charged with palming $28,000 in phones, wallets, and computers.

He landed on NYPD‚Äôs radar on March 2 after he swiped a fanny pack from a Times Square dosa shop and racked up $1,200 in credit card charges in just 20 minutes, according to the victim, an international student from India.

The victim told The Post that he forgot his bag at the eatery for just a few minutes, and it was gone when he came back. Good Samaritans pointed out the thief, whom he described as a ‚Äúlittle old man‚Äù wearing a COVID mask.

Cops swooped on Bustamante-Leiva in about 30 minutes, but the damage was already done, and the student had tons of unauthorized charges on his card, he said.

The victim, who lives in Jersey City and asked not to be named, said he‚Äôs furious that Bustamante-Leiva was let go with just a desk appearance ticket after being arrested.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs insane. I don‚Äôt know how he was let out after that without any reason,‚Äù the student said.

‚ÄúI mean, putting in so much effort and then coming to the States and experiencing something like that intrigued my frightened side.‚Äù

He said he‚Äôs still out $500 that the credit card company never reimbursed him for.

After his arrest, NYPD cops gave Bustamante-Leiva, who said he lived in the Bronx, a desk appearance ticket on fourth-degree felony grand larceny charges and released him. When he didn‚Äôt show up for his court date, officers went looking for him, law enforcement sources said.

New York‚Äôs sanctuary laws meant that the NYPD was not allowed to report him to federal immigration authorities, despite being in the country illegally.

‚ÄúYears ago, people would be held on ICE detainers if somebody was known to be in the country unlawfully and committed crimes,‚Äù former Manhattan prosecutor Mark A. Bederow fumed. ‚ÄúThat would be a no-brainer hold ‚Ä¶ these kinds of crimes would not be committed if the policies were stronger. That‚Äôs just the reality.‚Äù

It‚Äôs unclear whether Bustamante-Leiva‚Äôs previous busts showed up on his criminal record when Manhattan cops arrested him and let him go.

It‚Äôs common for the NYPD to hand out tickets and court dates to people arrested for lower-level theft, even if it‚Äôs a felony.

Bustamante-Leiva and his accomplice in the Noem bag snatch, Cristian Rodrigo Montecino-Sanzana, are believed to be part of a large East Coast robbery organization, sources said.

The two men allegedly worked together and have committed similar robbery schemes across the US, sources said.

Bustamante-Leiva told investigators that he‚Äôs an alcoholic and that he has memory problems, but he clearly remembered taking the Gucci bag. He said he kept the wallet and the purse ‚Äî but dumped the other contents in the trash, according to docs.

He claimed to have no idea who Noem was and didn‚Äôt remember who he stole from.

In addition to his splurge at the DC red-sauce joint, feds accused Bustamante-Leiva of using the ill-gotten gains from a string of other robberies nearby in the preceding days ‚Äì again blowing other people‚Äôs cash to buy booze, including a bottle of Josh cabernet sauvignon at a DC supermarket.

He also bought gift cards worth hundreds of dollars with credit cards and cash from stolen bags, prosecutors said.

In those incidents ‚Äì two on April 17, at a DC coffee shop and a Westin Hotel restaurant, and one at another restaurant on April 12 ‚Äî Bustamante-Leiva demonstrated his sticky-fingered prowess by slyly approaching his victims and slipping bags from their chairs, or using his legs to covertly inch their belongings closer to him, security footage showed.

In the April 12 theft, he was careful to slip a jacket over his arm before approaching his victim, and with the help of an accomplice, allegedly swiped the bag from his victim and hid it under his coat before walking off.

He used credit cards from that theft for stays at a Motel 6 and a Quality Inn over the following days, the documents alleged.

Bustamante-Leiva¬†was taken into custody in Washington, DC, on Saturday, while his alleged accomplice was nabbed in Miami on Sunday.

Additional reporting by Priscilla DeGregory, Emily Crane, and Alex Oliveira.
item.author: Jennie Taer, Joe Marino

item.title: ÊùéÁà∏Áà∏ËØ¥ÔºåÂú®‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊãôÂä£ÁöÑÂåÖÁöÆÁéØÂàáÊúØÂêéÔºåÂ©¥ÂÑøÂÑøÂ≠êÊ≠£Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂåªÈô¢‰∏∫Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑÁîüÂëΩËÄåÊàòÔºö ‚Äú‰ªñÁúãËµ∑Êù•ÂÉèÊòØÁªèÂéÜËøáÊàò‰∫â‚Äù | LI dad says infant son is fighting for his life in NYC hospital after a botched circumcision: ‚ÄòHe looks like he‚Äôs been through war‚Äô
item.description:
A Long Island dad says what should have been a routine circumcision for his newborn son in a New York City hospital has left the little guy fighting for his life.

Cole Jordan Groth was born on March 31 at NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children‚Äôs Hospital ‚Äî although he was diagnosed with a congenital heart disease, he was otherwise healthy ‚Äî and scheduled to go home with his parents to meet his two-year-old older brother at their Long Island house in Lake Grove on April 16.

Two days prior, the doctors called Tim Groth, and his wife Gabrielle, asking if they wanted to have their son circumcised, and what transpired turned into a ‚Äúparent‚Äôs worst nightmare,‚Äù Groth, 35, told The Post Monday.

Within a few hours of the common procedure, the infant nearly bled to death, started having seizures and suffered damage to multiple organs, the dad said.

When his wife came to the hospital to go over her son‚Äôs discharge the next day on April 15, she discovered the baby boy was ‚Äúpale, screaming and despondent,‚Äù Groth said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just horrible,‚Äù he added.

Over the next 10 days, Cole had to receive blood transfusions daily and had multiple surgeries ‚Äî including one on his stomach since parts of his intestines had failed due to the blood loss.

The boy, who remains in critical condition, was put on a respirator, given pain medications, has a colostomy bag to go to the bathroom and is receiving all his nutrition intravenously, Groth said.

‚ÄúHe looks like he‚Äôs been through war,‚Äù the dad added. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs pale, vascular ‚Ä¶ you see the hole in his stomach for the ostomy bag. ‚ÄúPart of me is really angry.

‚ÄúAll of it was so avoidable and so unnecessary. Part of me is really sad. My son is obviously suffering ‚Ä¶ you wouldn‚Äôt wish this on your worst enemy.‚Äù

The father filed a grievance with the hospital searching for answers.

He explained that his son‚Äôs bleeding was discovered by a nurse around 2:30 a.m. on April 15 but it wasn‚Äôt until after 5 a.m. that blood work was finally ordered. And the attending doctor wasn‚Äôt notified until 8:30 a.m., during a shift change, about what was happening.

‚ÄúThey failed to stop the bleeding and failed to identify and diagnose how much blood he lost,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt go from a circumcision to a baby nearly bleeding to death and have done things the right way.‚Äù

Baby Cole faces a long road to recovery.

He‚Äôs expected to remain in the cardiac neonatal intensive care unit for months as doctors hope to eventually perform another surgery to reconnect his intestines so they can remove the colostomy bag.

The family set up a GoFundMe page on April 19 hoping to raise $50,000 to pay for the months of treatment now needed. As of Monday afternoon, the page for Cole had received nearly $60,000 in donations.

And there have been some positive signs ‚Äî the baby hasn‚Äôt required a blood transfusion in several days. But his parents are still bracing for any long-term implications.

‚ÄúI spent my time crying,‚Äù Groth said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve gotten to the point now where I have to deal with it. Now it‚Äôs a lifetime of we have to figure out what‚Äôs the next complication.‚Äù

Throughout the harrowing ordeal, the hospital, Groth said, has been sympathetic, but also careful not to admit any wrongdoing.

‚ÄúThey have done their best to show as much compassion and empathy as they can without really having any sort of accountability,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey have chosen their words wisely.‚Äù

A spokesperson for NewYork-Presbyterian told The Post that they couldn‚Äôt comment, citing ‚Äúpatient privacy policies.‚Äù

Groth works as a CEO running a pain management practice on Long Island that his father, a doctor, founded. He said his father and other family members ‚Äî also in the medical industry ‚Äî have told him Cole‚Äôs case shows the hospital ‚Äúdefinitely‚Äù didn‚Äôt follow the ‚Äústandard of care‚Äù or ‚Äúact urgently enough.‚Äù

The distraught dad said he hasn‚Äôt lawyered up yet, but admitted he hasn‚Äôt ruled out legal action down the road.

‚ÄúAt the end of the day, we are kind of just still hoping that he lives,‚Äù Groth said.
item.author: Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: MTAÂ£∞Áß∞Âú∞ÈìÅÊõ¥ÂÆâÂÖ®ÔºåÂêåÊó∂ÊåáË¥£ÁâπÊúóÊôÆÁÆ°ÁêÜÂëòÁ≥üÁ≥ïÁöÑÂ£∞Ë™â‚Äî straphangers‰ªçÁÑ∂‚ÄúÂÆ≥ÊÄïs‚Äìtless‚Äù | MTA claims subways are safer while pointing finger at Trump admin for bad rep ‚Äî¬† straphangers still ‚Äòscared s‚Äìtless‚Äô
item.description:
A recent rash of violent Big Apple subway attacks has straphangers riding in fear again ‚Äî even as MTA brass blames the Trump administration for fanning the flames.

Metropolitan Transportation Authority member Gerard Bringmann complained Monday about US Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy‚Äôs depiction of the subway as dangerous and crime ridden.

‚ÄúPersonally, I‚Äôm just getting tired of hearing all this from Secretary Duffy about how unsafe our system is and yet the testimony here is we‚Äôre bending over backwards to make our system as safe as possible,‚Äù Bringmann said during an MTA public safety meeting. ‚ÄúApparently they‚Äôre not getting the message,‚Äù

But while transit agency bosses maintain the subways are among the safest urban systems in the US, everyday New Yorkers told The Post it‚Äôs the MTA that‚Äôs not getting the message.

Debbie Fuchs, 68, from the Upper West Side has been catching the subway for 30 years, and said crime is worse than ever.¬†

‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared s‚Äîtless catching the subway,‚Äù Upper West Sider Debbie Fuchs, 68, said Monday. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm always looking around for the crazies. You‚Äôre never relaxed on the train.¬†I‚Äôm afraid of being shoved on the track.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt stand near the edge of the platform. I‚Äôll stand by a pole and I‚Äôll hang on to it. I don‚Äôt trust anybody on the subway,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúCrime on the subway has been getting worse for the past two years.‚Äù

Another Manhattanite who asked not to be identified said thanks, but no thanks.

‚ÄúI used to catch the subway every day. Crime got a lot worse and I stopped catching it entirely,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs enough crime above ground without exposing yourself below ground. I would go back on the subway if I had a great, big bodyguard.‚Äù

Duffy has been another critic, and quipped last week that Gov. Kathy Hochul‚Äôs congestion pricing plan, which aims to push more New Yorkers onto a risky subway system, was ‚Äúliberal insanity.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt ride the subway, she‚Äôs got a detail that drives her around,‚Äù Duffy snapped. ‚ÄúSo she may not care about the experience of MTA riders, but she should.‚Äù

In a report over the weekend, The Post revealed that felony assaults in the transit system are up 9% so far this year, and a staggering 55% over the same period in 2019, according to NYPD data.

In one of the latest incidents, a 29-year-old man was shoved into the side of a No. 2 train at a station at West 96th Street and Broadway, sending him to Bellevue Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

The suspect fled the station and hasn‚Äôt been to court, law enforcement sources said.

But on Monday MTA Chairman Janno Lieber said crime is under control in the New York City system, which he said is much safer than many other major cities.

He said the agency sent Duffy a 20-page report detailing safety and security improvements.

‚ÄúContrary to some of the stuff that‚Äôs thrown around, the MTA on a per capita basis is among the very safest transit systems in the United States,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre nine times more likely to be the victim of a felony crime in the Houston of Minneapolis or Dallas system. I think it‚Äôs eight times more in the Chicago system. We‚Äôre not in competition.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not putting anyone down but you have to look at the stats,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúAnd by those standards New York is very safe. We have made that point time and time again.‚Äù

MTA Police Chief Thomas Taffe said overall crime in the city subways is down 2.2% since March and down 18% so far during this quarter.

Taffe said there are now more than 135,000 surveillance cameras across the transit system, including trains, subways, bridges and tunnels ‚Äî 17,000 more than in February 2024.
item.author: Haley Brown, Jack Morphet, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: ÂÅáÊï¥ÂΩ¢Â§ñÁßëÂåªÁîüÊèèËø∞‰∫ÜÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â¶àÂ¶àÂú®ÊãôÂä£ÁöÑËáÄÈÉ®Ê§çÂÖ•ÊâãÊúØ‰∏≠Ê≠ª‰∫°ÂâçÁöÑÊúÄÂêéÊó∂ÂàªÔºö ‚ÄúÊàëÊÉäÊÖåÂ§±Êé™‚Äù | Sham plastic surgeon describes NYC mom‚Äôs final moments before dying in botched butt implant procedure: ‚ÄòI panicked‚Äô
item.description:
The sham doctor charged with killing a mom of two described to cops how his patient started slurring her words and lost consciousness following a botched butt-implant removal procedure at his Queens apartment ‚Äî prompting him to panic, prosecutors revealed Monday.

Felipe Hoyos Foronda, 37, was moments from boarding a flight to Florida at JFK Airport when police nabbed him on March 28, just hours after Maria Penaloza was left-brain dead by the illegal $1,900 procedure in his Astoria living room, according to an indictment.

‚ÄúI injected her in the ass,‚Äù he allegedly told cops bluntly when he was hauled back to the precinct for questioning.

‚ÄúAfter I injected her, she started to speak funny, then she stopped speaking, and then she tensed up,‚Äù Foronda continued, according to prosecutors.

‚ÄúSlurred speech is normal during this type of anesthesia,‚Äù he allegedly insisted, while noting, ‚Äúeven though, after she tightened up, she didn‚Äôt respond.‚Äù

Penaloza, 31, was rushed to the hospital by paramedics, and Foronda then hastily cleaned up the room and made a beeline for the airport, prosecutors said.

He booked a flight to Florida en route to Colombia, ‚Äúso he could evade arrest and prosecution, because he claimed he was scared,‚Äù Queens Assistant District Attorney Gregory Lasak, Jr., said in court Monday.

Outside the courtroom, Penaloza‚Äôs mother, Gladys Cabrera, blasted the accused quack as ‚Äúan assassin.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a danger to society. This was premeditated,‚Äù she said through tears.

The dead woman‚Äôs sister, Lucy Penaloza, called for Foronda to ‚Äúpay the consequences.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe family is paying the consequences and we‚Äôre waiting for him to suffer the full weight of the law,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHow many women have been affected by him?‚Äù

According to prosecutors, Foronda admitted to having done the type of procedure that led to Penaloza‚Äôs death ‚Äúhundreds of times,‚Äù telling cops, ‚ÄúWord of mouth has given me my business.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been practicing in that apartment for a few months,‚Äù he said, despite also fessing up that ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a licensed doctor here. I understand that I‚Äôm not allowed to practice medicine.‚Äù

Prosecutors said Penaloza went to Foronda to have implants removed and was led into the living room of his Astoria apartment ‚Äî a makeshift operating room ‚Äî where she was hooked up to an IV of lidocaine.

‚ÄúShe began to slur her speech,‚Äù Queens Assistant District Attorney Gregory Lasak, Jr., said in court. ‚ÄúHer body began to tense up, and she eventually went into cardiac arrest.

‚ÄúFirefighters and EMTs responded to the location and work on the victim on scene for approximately 30 minutes, attempting to revive her,‚Äù Lasak said. ‚ÄúBut when they arrived, she was pulseless and she wasn‚Äôt breathing. Eventually, the victim was moved to Mount Sinai in Astoria, where staff in the emergency room continued to administer life saving measures to attempt to save her life.

‚ÄúShe went approximately two hours without a pulse, and the damage to her body was irreversible.‚Äù¬†

Cops caught up with Foronda moments before he boarded his flight, as he waited on line at a Starbucks at the terminal, and hauled him back to the Queens stationhouse, Lasak said.

‚ÄúI panicked, I went straight to the airport. I booked the flight while I was driving,‚Äù he allegedly told detectives.

Cops searched his car and found a bag on the floor with used syringes, latex gloves and an empty bottle of lidocaine that ‚Äúappeared that it was removed from the location,‚Äù according to prosecutors.

On Monday, Foronda was arraigned on a grand jury indictment charging him with second-degree manslaughter, second degree assault and unauthorized practice of a profession.

‚ÄúWe are not okay,‚Äù said Valentina Penaloza, the victim‚Äôs niece. ‚ÄúWe want justice. This was a murder.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Desheania Andrews, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Â∑ûÈïøHochulÂíåÁ´ãÊ≥ïËÄÖÂÆ£Â∏ÉÂ∞±Á∫ΩÁ∫¶È¢ÑÁÆó2540‰∫øÁæéÂÖÉËææÊàêÂàùÊ≠•ÂçèËÆÆ‚ÄîÊà™Ê≠¢Êó•ÊúüÂêé28Â§© | Gov. Hochul and legislators announce preliminary deal on $254B NY budget ‚Äî 28 days after deadline
item.description:
ALBANY ‚Äì Gov. Kathy Hochul finally announced a $254 billion budget deal with lawmakers Monday ‚Äì nearly a month after blowing through the deadline for the spending plan.

Hochul said the massive spending plan would include ‚Äúinflation refund‚Äù checks to 8.2 million New Yorkers, a cellphone ban in schools and an agreement to strengthen laws to involuntarily commitment the mentally ill.

It is also expected to include a tax hike on businesses meant to fund the MTA‚Äôs $68 billion five-year capital plan.

The announcment came after a drawn-out standoff between Hochul and fellow Democrats in control of the state legislature after the governor pitched a slightly smaller $252 billion spending plan.

The two sides have been haggling over the governor‚Äôs policy asks ‚Äî including a marquee public safety proposal to revamp discovery laws, which govern evidence-sharing requirements in criminal cases.

For several weeks, Hochul refused to budge on her proposal meant to stymie a wave of what she deemed as frivolous criminal case dismissals under the 2019 discovery laws signed into law by former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who is now running for New York City mayor.

That logjam largely cleared after Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie (D-Bronx) effectively got out in front of Hochul and announced the legislature had worked out an agreement with the five New York City district attorneys to change laws around how evidence is shared ahead of criminal trials.

Negotiators plan to finish locking down technical details following the ‚Äúhandshake‚Äù agreement, and put together the nine remaining legislative bills that lawmakers will vote on, likely as soon as later this week.

This is Hochul‚Äôs fourth state budget since taking over for Cuomo in the fall of 2021, and the second to last she needs to pass ahead of her planned 2026 reelection bid.
item.author: Vaughn Golden
